div1.p: The writer offers a political explanation for Ross's actions.

div1.head: Letter to Howard A. Kelly, [19--]
div1.opener:
New York,
Confidential
Dr. Howard Kelly,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Doctor Kelly:-
div1.p:
I received a letter from you the other day, which was
evidently intended for John, in which you said that in a letter written
by Dr. Carroll, he stated that he was not able to get blood to test
yellow fever at Las Animas Hospital, because Dr. Guiteras objected and the
objection was sustained by Major Ross.

John at present has charge of the Los Animas Hospital, and lives
with his family on the grounds. It is of course a Government position
given to him by President Palma during his administration. From what
I hear a number of physicians of the other party would like very much
to have the position, and as there is great jealousy in Cuba, as well as
graft, he is very careful what he says and does, as some of his colleagues
might take advantage of it to claim that he was using the material and
specimens obtained from patients for unnecessary purposes. Probably
Major Ross understands the Cuban character, and for this reason upheld him
in his refusal. He would, doubtless, have been very glad to have given
these specimens of blood to Dr. Carroll if he had not thought that it
such an action might be used against him by some who are desirous of having his place.

The Spanish character is very different from that of the American,
and I am sorry to say that in Cuba, positions like John's are obtained
more frequently through political pull and graft, than through merit
and scientific knowledge.

I read with great ineterest the book by Hopkins describing his
life in Africa, and have not quite finished it. As soon as I do, I will
send it to you.

Remember me to Mrs. Kelly and the children, and
believe me,
div1.closer:
Yours sincerely, Ramonreiters B. you understand when I mean this by this letter.
If he were to give a specimen of blood, some one
might report in one of the Cuban papers, result which
are very sensational, resulting perhaps in the loss of his
hospital place and his house.
PS
